articles.summary: Georgia's Superintendent of Schools, Richard Woods, has reversed course after initially refusing to provide funding for a new Advanced Placement class in African American Studies. articles.summary: The Supreme Court's decision to overturn Chevron deference, which allows courts to defer to agencies like the FCC in interpreting ambiguous parts of the law, could potentially kill net neutrality. This ruling means that internet service providers should not be able to discriminate between services on the internet. The Sixth Circuit immediately halted the FCC’s new net neutrality order and asked for briefs on how the Loper Bright ruling would change the case. This decision is seen as a major power grab for the judiciary over the other two branches of government, with implications for the environment, labor law, and regulation.

articles.summary: The federal government has announced over $41 million in contributions and low-cost loans through the Affordable Housing Fund (AHF) to help build and repair 3,304 affordable homes in Ottawa and Eastern Ontario. The announcement was made by the Honourable Jenna Sudds, Minister of Families, Children and Social Development and Member of Parliament for Kanata—Carleton. The funding is helping create 86 new homes and is leading to the repairs of 3,218 homes. The Affordable Housing fund provides funding through low-interest and/or forgivable loans or contributions to partnered organizations for new affordable housing and the renovation and repair of existing, affordable and community housing. The fund is part of a $13.2 billion program under the National Housing Strategy (NHS) that prioritises projects that help those in need.

articles.summary: Kamala Harris, former California attorney general, has been known for supporting affordable housing and has proposed similar policies as a potential presidential candidate. Her proposed Rent Relief Act would offer tax credits to renters who earn below $100,000 and spend over 30% of their income on rent and utilities. This version includes a mechanism from the Treasury to pay the tax credit monthly to eligible households. The second version caps the credit at 100% of small area fair market rents instead of 150% of FMR. This comes as Harris announced the recipients of an $85 million grant under the Pathways to Removing Obstacles for Housing, or PRO Housing, aimed to increase building activity and lower housing and rental costs for families in the U.S. The LIFT the Middle Class Act would provide a refundable tax credit of up to $3,000 per person or $6,000 for married couples who file joint tax returns. Some experts suggest that the LIFT Act might be better for renters than the proposed 5% rent cap increase, which could lead to landlords losing access to tax breaks.

articles.title: 83(b) Election: Tax Strategies For Unvested Company Stock
articles.description: With an 83(b) election, you pay tax on unvested shares now. For founders and executives with stock options or restricted stock, it can be a powerful tax planning tool.
articles.content: For founders, employees, and executives with stock-based compensation, an 83(b) election can be a powerful tax planning tool. When you make an 83(b) election, you're opting to pay tax on unvested shar... [7765 symbols]
articles.summary: An 83(b) election, a powerful tax planning tool for founders, employees, and executives with stock-based compensation, can accelerate the taxation of unvested company stock. The election, which minimizes taxable income and controls the timing of it, allows individuals to pay tax on these shares now, instead of when they vest. This includes paying tax on the taxable spread at grant, rather than when the stock vesting requirements. The difference between the exercise (or purchase) price and the current fair market value of the stock is taxable, either as ordinary income (for restricted stock and non-qualified stock options) or for the alternative minimum tax (AMT) calculation (for incentive stock options). The election can be made in conjunction with an early exercise of stock options or profits interests in an LLC or partnership. Startup founders, early employees, executives, and other service providers can also make an 83B election. The key benefit of this election is having more control over your tax situation and equity. An 83B) election can also be made to shift taxable income entirely to more favorable long-term rates. The eligibility period for this election includes qualifying small business stock (Section 1202) and qualifying for tax-free stock sales.

articles.summary: Kingston, New York, has received a $538,409 state grant for its Food Scraps Compost Program, part of over $7.3 million awarded to municipalities across the state through the Climate Smart Communities grant program. The grant will be used to expand the program, which has significantly reduced the amount of food waste sent to the landfill. The program, launched in 2023, has been highly successful and has diverted 33.65 tons of food from the Seneca Meadows Landfill. The cost of disposing of food scraps costs $20 per ton per ton, compared to $115 per ton for disposing solid waste, reduces carbon emissions and reduces waste by fewer truck trips to the Senec landfill. With the grant, Kingston will implement a five-pronged organics diversion program.

articles.summary: HarperCollins Publishers is planning massive reprints to meet demand for JD Vance's book, "Hillbilly Elegy," following his selection by former President Donald Trump as his running mate. The publisher announced that over 600,000 copies of the book have been sold since Trump's announcement on July 15. The book, which tells of Vance's childhood in Ohio and his family's roots in rural Kentucky, was widely cited as essential reading for understanding Trump's appeal to working class whites after his victory in 2016. Despite criticism, the book has been adapted into a feature film.

articles.summary: Donald Trump supporters in North Carolina are not confident that Vice President Kamala Harris' entry into the 2024 race will significantly impact the results in November. The Democratic Party has claimed an 'enthusiasm boost' after President Joe Biden stepped aside and Harris took over his campaign. However, some Trump supporters believe this is a ruse. They believe that Democrats are being'really quiet' in the state, where North Carolina is a must-win state for 2024. In 2016, Trump won by 3.6 percent and in 2020, but still beat Biden by 1.3 percent. The Democrat Party plans to double their workforce in the next two weeks and start staffing up six months earlier than in previous election cycles.

articles.summary: The United States figure skating team is confirmed as the gold medalists for the 2022 Olympics by a sports court ruling. The Court of Arbitration for Sport dismissed Russian appeals to be reinstated as the team event gold medalist, following the loss of star skater Kamila Valieva in a doping case. The ruling ensures that the U.S. team will receive their medals at the Paris Summer Games. Special medal ceremonies are planned for the Paris Olympics to honor athletes whose results have been upgraded due to doping cases. The Canadian team is awaiting a verdict in a separate appeal to be upgraded from fourth to third, knocking Russia off the podium.

articles.title: House Votes To Establish Task Force On Trump Assassination Attempt
articles.description: The House of Representatives voted unanimously on Wednesday night to establish a task force to investigate the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump earlier this month at a campaign rally in western Pennsylvania.  Rep. Mike Kelly (R-PA) introduced the resolution that passed 416-0 in support. The vote comes as the Judiciary and Oversight Committees have ...

articles.summary: The House of Representatives voted unanimously to establish a task force to investigate the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump. The resolution, introduced by Rep. Mike Kelly (R-PA), passed 416-0. The task force will investigate all actions by any agency, Department, Officer, or Employee of the federal government, State and Local law enforcement, and private entities related to the assassination of Trump on July 13, 2024. The majority of the 13 members will be selected by House Speaker Mike Johnson (R/LA). The taskforce must issue a final report of its findings to the House by December 13, 2025, including recommendations for legislative reforms to prevent future security lapses.

articles.summary: The FBI conducted a pre-dawn raid on the $3.5 million Long Island home of Linda Sun, a former deputy chief of staff to Gov. Kathy Hochul. The five-bedroom home was searched thoroughly by agents from the US Attorney’s Office in Brooklyn. The reason for the raid was unclear and Sun and her husband, Chris Hu, have not been accused of any criminal activity. Sun, who has worked in various government roles across New York State, left state service last year following allegations of misconduct that were serious enough to be referred to law enforcement.

articles.summary: The band's stage persona has changed significantly since their early stage persona in 2004, with their focus on the serious nature of their music. Daniel Kessler, Paul Banks, and AdamJosephByrne, who have been together for 20 years, discuss their appreciation of the connection between their music and their audience. They also share their fondest memories from recording or touring Antics, which had leaked and fans in Spain came up to them talking about it. The band was concerned about losing respect for their song "Untitled" in Friends, but avoided certain commercial licences to avoid potentially undermining their legitimacy. They have also shared memories of being stranded on the bus during a tour in 2014, including being stuck outside Buffalo for days.

articles.title: Democrats to virtually nominate Harris—and her running mate—by Aug. 7
articles.description: Democratic National Convention delegates can make Vice President Kamala Harris their presidential nominee—and even start approving her yet-to be-named running mate—in online voting beginning ...

articles.summary: The Democratic National Convention delegates will be able to virtually nominate Vice President Kamala Harris as their presidential nominee, or even her running mate, in online voting beginning Aug. 1. The rules committee approved a proposal that delegates from around the country could vote on potential presidential nominees to replace President Joe Biden, who ended his reelection bid. Harris is the only major Democrat to announce publicly that she is seeking the nomination, meaning she will likely be approved in a single round of virtual balloting. The process requires 300 electronic signatures from convention delegates by July 30, not more than 50 of whom can be from the same state. If multiple candidates qualify, it could lead to multiple rounds of voting over several days. Delegates voting "uncommitted" or for another candidate who hasn't qualified under the rules, will have their choices converted to "present."

Tech leaders, including Sheryl Sandberg, Reed Hastings, and Melinda French Gates, have endorsed Harris. This is in stark contrast to former President Donald Trump's White House bid. Despite her connections with tech industry, Harris has also pushed for tech accountability in key areas such as AI safety measures and transparency among top tech firms and the government. She can also claim to some of the pro-tech actions taken by the Biden administration, including the Chips Act, which set aside funding for US-production of critical computing components.

Graczyk, a development manager with Great Lakes Bay, believes her connections in the community will allow her to hear the concerns of her neighbors. Kokaly, a branch area manager with Aunt Millie Bakeries, said his experience with payrolls, schedules, and having to make the hard decisions make him a good candidate. Swartz identified the most pressing issues facing the city, including failing infrastructure and a lack of trust.

articles.title: Millions can’t get paid family leave in N.J. to care for newborns or sick relatives
articles.description: The state law allowing you to take time to care for a sick relative or a newborn has a gaping loophole.
articles.content: New Jersey’s paid family leave program — which allows people to take time off to care for a sick relative or a new baby while collecting 85% of their earnings — all but excludes more than 1.7 million ... [930 symbols]

keywords.name: New Jersey’s paid family leave program

entities.data: the Center for Women and Work
School of Management and Labor Relations

articles.summary: New Jersey's paid family leave program, which allows people to take time off to care for sick relatives or a new baby while earning 85% of their earnings, excludes over 1.7 million hourly workers due to the law not allowing employers to fire them. To participate in the program, workers must have worked at the same employer for a year and have logged at least 1,000 hours of work. This loophole excludes younger hourly employees, typically women in healthcare, food preparation and education fields. A study by Rutgers University suggests that lawmakers should loosen these requirements so people are not forced to lose a job at their family's greatest time of needs.

articles.summary: Israel has warned that Iranian terrorists are planning an attack on Israelis at the 2024 Paris Olympics. Israeli Foreign Minister Israel Katz has informed his French counterpart, Stéphane Séjourné, of an alleged Iranian-backed plot to attack the Israeli delegation of athletes. Despite acknowledging the "unprecedented security measures" in place by French security forces to protect Israelis attending the games, Katz also noted that French authorities have rejected calls from the Left to ban all Israeli participants from the Olympics. There are currently 88 Israeli athletes at the games and they have been given unprecedented protection from both French and Israeli security services. However, there is no evidence linking the alleged attack to the Paris Olympics yet.

articles.title: JD Vance Has a Political Statement on His Face
articles.description: It’s been more than a century since a sitting president or vice president sported a beard. He’s in politically uncharted, potentially risky territory.
articles.content: “He’s either the tip of the iceberg or a very unusual aberration: It depends on whether people follow suit,” Christopher Oldstone-Moore, the author of Of Beards And Men: The Revealing History of Facia... [3184 symbols]
articles.summary: Christopher Oldstone-Moore, author of Of Beards And Men: The Revealing History of Facial Hair, has noted that politics will determine whether the return of beards is on the rise. The late 19th century and early 20th century saw a significant increase in beards and facial hair in the White House, with nine of the next 11 presidents having either a beard or a mustache. However, this trend ended when William Taft, the 27th president, was replaced by King Camp Gillette's safety razor invention in 1901, which made shaving easier and more accessible. The association of clean-shavenness with regularity, efficiency, cooperation, and reliability was a key masculine value in the 20th Century and present, according to the author. Researchers at Oklahoma State University found that voters perceived those with beards as more masculine and more competent, but they also perceived them as less supportive of feminist issues and less likely to support women's rights.

articles.title: Does your vote really count in the Electoral College?
articles.description: Political analysts keep reminding us that this is the most important election of our lifetime; at the same time, they are also insisting that the outcome of the race comes down to a handful of stat…

articles.summary: The 2024 presidential election has been marked by tension between Joe Biden and his party over calls for him to step aside due to concerns he won't win in November. However, the outcome of the race could hinge on voters in just three of the 50 states, Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin, and maybe a handful of others. This is a unique situation in America, where even winning the popular vote does not guarantee electoral victory. The article suggests that the Electoral College may no longer be serving today's voter in politically polarized times and suggests that it is time for a change.

articles.summary: Akima, a provider of products and services to the federal government, has secured a $480 million contract to support the U.S. Space Force's Satellite Operations. The contract will require Akima's expertise in providing essential mission support services. The company will manage the operation and maintenance of the Space Force’s primary Satellite Control Network (SCN), a crucial system for the launch and daily control of U.K. government satellites. The partnership with the Space force is set to set the stage for significant advancements in satellite control and space defense operations. Akima is a global enterprise with 10,000 employees and is owned by an Alaska Native Corporation owned by over 15,000 Iñupiat shareholders.

She questioned why he did not discuss these issues during his address to the nation, stating that he could still serve and wanted to bring the party together. Biden had previously stated that he planned to serve out the rest of his term and had chosen to pass the torch to a new generation. After endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris, Biden quickly stated that the election was up to the American people.

On Thursday, Trump appeared on Fox News' Fox & Friends and spoke about recent pro... [2529 symbols]
articles.summary: Donald Trump's plan for his second presidency could challenge past rulings by the U.S. Supreme Court. Speaking on Fox News' Fox & Friends, Trump called for those who burn or damage the American flag to receive a "one-year jail sentence." This follows recent pro-Palestinian protests in Washington, D.C. ahead of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's joint address to Congress. The calls for penalties for such acts violate a past ruling by the Supreme Court in 1989, which stated that a man who burned the flag was using a form of "symbolic speech" protected by the First Amendment. In response, Congress passed the Flag Protection Act of 1989, but the court ruled it unconstitutional in 1990.

During a rally in North Carolina, Trump mentioned Lecter as his next VP. This reference has been made numerous times throughout the campaign, with many believing it is related to the term'mental asylum' and "asylum seeker". These theories suggest that Trump may confuse the definition of asylum and mistakenly believe all immigrants seeking asylum are automatically insane. However, it is unclear whether Trump believes Lecter is alive or not. The use of the phrase "the late, great Hannibal Lecters" suggests that he might be unable to distinguish fiction from reality.

His supporters praised him for placing the truth on the most important stage in the world. However, critics accused him of being absurd and cynical. While Netanyahu made no mention of the ceasefire agreement under negotiation, the families of Israeli hostages held by Hamas expressed anger. They accused him deliberately sabotaging their chances of bringing their loved ones home. Hamas suggested that it would have been better to arrest Netanyahu as a war criminal and give him the opportunity to cover up mass ethnic cleansing in the Gaza Strip.

The Palestinian Liberation Organization (PLO) also condemned the speech, accusing Israel of starving Gaza and of using it as a cover to “escape punishment". Hamas responded by accusing Netanyahu of spreading propaganda and giving him an opportunity to cover up mass killings and ethnic cleansing in Gaza.

This is particularly crucial as reproductive rights are at risk and one third of women live in a state where they lack the ability to make their own decisions about their own body and healthcare. Political scientist Erik C. articles.title: What history says about V.P. picks: senator, governor or wild card?
articles.description: Kamala Harris could be better served — at least politically — by a certain kind of pick.
articles.content: We know this much: Vice President Kamala Harris will pick her running mate before accepting her party’s presidential nomination in August at the Democratic National Convention. Harris also has a short... [4985 symbols]
articles.summary: The history of vice presidential picks has been examined since 1945 to determine whether a senator, governor, or a non-elected U.S. House representative will be chosen as a running mate for the upcoming Vice President election. Since 1945, presidential candidates have made 31 vice presidential choices, with 19 most recently served in elected office as U.K. senators, four governors, and seven who had prior electoral experience only from the House of Representatives. Democrats have chosen a senator in 16 cases since 1945, while Republicans have been more diverse in their selections. The historical record indicates that the prior job of the running mate makes little difference in victory or defeat if it is a senator or governor. However, those without gubernatorial or senatorial experience have fared poorly.

This comes after a police officer was filmed apparently stamping on a man's head at the airport. After the clip was widely shared online, hundreds of protesters gathered outside a Rochdale police station and chanted "Allahu Akbar". Labour MPs have also raised concerns with senior officers in Greater Manchester Police regarding the incident. Burnham stated that he would work with the Independent Office for Police Conduct to ensure a high level of neutrality in its investigation. His comments came as Akhmed Yakoob, a lawyer who ran as an independent at the election on a pro-Gaza ticket, released a video of himself with two men arrested at Manchester Airport.

articles.summary: Kamala Harris' campaign team is reportedly vetting retired Admiral William McRaven, who oversaw the May 2011 Navy SEAL raid that killed Osama bin Laden, as a potential 2024 running mate for Vice President Kamala Harris. Other potential candidates include Arizona Senator Mark Kelly, Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro, and Kentucky Governor Andy Beshear. McRaven was commander of the U.S. Joint Special Operations Command between 2008 and 2011, and served as head of the United States Special Ops Command from August 2011 to 2014. He also served as Chancellor of the University of Texas System for over three years. As of Thursday morning, bookmaker William Hill had Senator Kelly as the firm favorite to be the Democrat's 2024 vice-presidential candidate with odds of 42.1 percent and 28.6 percent.

This comment was particularly notable as a reference to a jury verdict of nearly three dozen felonies. The comments were part of an attempt to counterbalance the criticism of former President Joe Biden's withdrawal from the 2024 race. This comes as part of a broader trend of suggesting that those who stand in his way are ineligible for American ballots should not be able to run. Despite this, Trump has a reputation for being anti-democracy and has previously stated that Hillary Clinton, Ted Cruz, John Kasich, and Joe Biden shouldn't have been "allowed" to run against him.

articles.content: Michael Burkheimer, a regular at Wings on Brookwood, claims in 2016 he ordered boneless chicken wings from the restaurant, but ended up with a bone lodged in his esophagus. It caused an infection that... [4029 symbols]
articles.summary: The Ohio Supreme Court ruled that just because you order boneless chicken wings from a restaurant does not mean you should expect to find bones in your food. In a 4-3 decision, Republicans on the Ohio Supreme court ruled that bones are a natural part of chicken and consumers should be on guard for them even in boneless wings. Democrats argued that a jury, not appeals court judges, should decide if customers should expect bones in bonless wings. The ruling provides legal protection to food businesses but could potentially lead to more serious consequences for those allergic to nuts or gluten.

Judge Mark Scarsi stated that these statements are not true and that Biden's counsel knows these statements. articles.summary: The National Gallery in London is set to display John Constable's 1821 painting, ‘The Hay Wain’ as a “contested landscape” in an upcoming exhibition. The painting depicts a rural landscape near Constable’s native Suffolk, but some critics argue it hides a hidden secret. The National Gallery curator, Dr Mary McMahon, stated that the painting was intended to explain the full social context of the painting and will be displayed alongside satirical images from the period. Other controversial exhibitions include a removal of a painting showing Jesus and other biblical figures depicted with Looney Tunes-style faces from a local gallery in Sydney, which was seen as undue censorship. Last year, Tate Britain changed its historical offering with an "inclusive" reimagining of its gallery, following a commitment to race equality.

articles.summary: The Supreme Court is facing four major requests for emergency relief, including a decision on student loan debt, Title IX, climate change standards, and former President Donald Trump's felony conviction. The case could be decided as early as today in Alaska v. Department of Education, which is being partially blocked by Republican state attorneys general in Alaska, South Carolina and Texas, could also be resolved. The Supreme Court previously struck down a plan by President Joe Biden that would have eliminated $430 billion in student loans for over 40 million borrowers. The Biden administration has also filed two emergency applications with the Supreme Court to narrow a pair of nationwide injunctions that blocked the Education Department's new Title IX rules from going into effect. The court's final ruling on the issue is expected before the end of the 2023-2024 term.

articles.summary: Former Lib Dem leader, Sir Vince Cable, has criticised Post Office managers for being "thugs in suits" and claimed he would have learned more about the Horizon IT scandal if MPs campaigning for branch owner-operators had met with him in person. Cable, who was business secretary for an unusually long period between 2010 and 2015, stated that he never learned who lead campaigner Sir Alan Bates was until before he left office and that he was not informed about the scandal's lead campaigner. He also expressed frustration that he only began to “smell a rat” in March 2015, just before parliament was dissolved. Cable agreed with the description of Post Office management as “thugs” and had a goal of improving the relationship between management and branch owners-operatives during his time in office. He admitted he should have been more thoroughly briefed on the Horizon system at the time.

articles.summary: A US bankruptcy judge dismissed a bankruptcy case filed by the Gateway Pundit, stating that the far-right outlet did not file the case in good faith. The decision comes as the outlet is facing defamation cases from two Georgia election workers and a former Dominion voting systems employee who allege the site spread false claims about them after the 2020 election. The judge stated that the site's assets were 22 times the size of its liabilities and that there is no present financial distress, no looming foreclosure sale, or prospect of a market crash. Filing for bankruptcy stops all civil proceedings against a business and allows it to consolidate litigation in one court.

articles.summary: The China-Russia axis is expanding into Europe, claiming Belarus and possibly Georgia. This move, along with the recent defense agreement between the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) and the Russian Federation, is seen as a strengthening of the anti-US, anti-Western axis. This axis includes Iran and is strengthening its ties with Russia’s ally Belarus. China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea are becoming a tightly-knit bloc that provides diplomatic support for each other and helps each heavily sanctioned member survive. The axis aims to diminish the influence of the United States while constraining the expansion of NATO. Belarus is part of this axis due to its deep political and military integration with Russia.

articles.summary: Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina wept as she surveyed the destruction caused by days of unrest, which resulted in the death of at least 193 people, including several police officers. The unrest was sparked by protests against a public jobs quota scheme that critics argue gives preference to allies of Hasina's ruling party. Despite the deaths, Hasina condemned protesters for damaging city infrastructure and ordered a curfew to allow free movement between 10:00 am and 5:00 pm. Students Against Discrimination, the group behind the protests, demanded an apology from Hasina for the mass murder of students and demanded the sacking of the home minister and education minister. The government has also been accused of misusing state institutions to maintain its grip on power and stamp out dissent.

articles.summary: Over 50 prominent artists, actors, artists, campaigners, and others from minority ethnic communities have written an open letter calling for the UK's voter ID laws to be scrapped. The signatories, including Sir Lenny Henry, the artist Anish Kapoor, Sophie Okonedo, Marianne Jean-Baptiste, David Harewood and Paterson Joseph, and the writer Kamila Shamsie, argued that the rules were an attack on the democratic rights of people of colour and that they should be abolished. The letter also called for automatic voter registration, where people are automatically added to the electoral roll by reference other databases rather than having to actively register. It criticises the Conservative government for introducing the law to further their own political interests, which the Conservatives reject.

She believes that individual sporting bodies should be able to decide whether to allow biological males to compete against women in their fields. She also stated that biology matters in sport and that it is impossible to ensure fairness without taking biology into account. The Football Association and the England and Wales Cricket Board are among those allowing transgender athletes to compete in female-only events if they meet certain criteria, such as low testosterone levels. The previous Tory government called for a total ban on trans people participating in elite-level women’s events. Nandy supports the trans community, stating that they are the most marginalised group of people in the country.

articles.summary: The author argues that while women in the United States of America have less money than men, they also have less net assets at the end of their careers. This is due to the higher education and higher-paying roles in finance and law that pay well. However, this gap has narrowed significantly as more women have higher education, work in finance, which pays well. The author suggests that men invest better in their money, reinvesting in the same types of instruments as women, and that their investments improve returns. She also suggests that if possible, owning real property over renting is an affordable investment, it would make it more affordable for a large slice of America. The article suggests that corporate stock ownership through stocks is a good way to achieve riches, as well as allowing corporations to retain the genius and strength of workers worldwide.

articles.title: Boeing finalizes plea deal with DOJ
articles.description: Boeing will plead guilty to defrauding the United States and pay a fine of $243 million after a pair of deadly Max crashes in 2018 and 2019.

articles.title: Harris meeting with teachers union in Houston
articles.description: Vice President Kamala Harris will stop in Houston, Texas, Thursday to address the American Federation of Teachers. This comes as Harris' first campaign video hits the web. CBS News campaign reporter Nidia Cavazos reports.
